channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Putin: Force last resort in Ukraine
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin says there is no need yet to send Russian troops into Ukraine, but he does not rule out doing so as a "last resort".

item.title: Hague warns Ukraine of 'provocation'
item.description: There is a serious risk that "provocation" could give rise to a dangerous incident in Ukraine, William Hague warns.

item.title: Pistorius neighbour 'heard fight'
item.description: A second witness at the murder trial of South African athlete Oscar Pistorius says she was awoken by the sounds of a fight in the early hours of 14 February 2013.

item.title: Brooks 'received death threats'
item.description: Former News of the World editor Rebekah Brooks says she received death threats after it was reported that murdered teenager Milly Dowler's phone had been hacked.

item.title: Tax cuts ahead, Cameron signals
item.description: David Cameron suggests that further public spending savings could be used to fund tax cuts.

item.title: Man 'wrote policeman-killing poem'
item.description: A poem about the killing of PC Keith Blakelock was written by the man accused of his murder during riots in north London in 1985, a court hears.

item.title: Childcare 'costs more than mortgage'
item.description: Many parents in Britain are now paying more for childcare in a year than the average annual mortgage bill, a report claims.

item.title: Scales has signs of 'early dementia'
item.description: Fawlty Towers star Prunella Scales has "a sort of mild Alzheimer's", her husband Tim West reveals in an interview.

item.title: Teacher 'taped pupils' mouths up'
item.description: A teacher is suspended following claims that tape was put over the mouths of several pupils.

item.title: NHS boss's Stafford Hospital regret
item.description: Outgoing NHS boss Sir David Nicholson says he "bitterly" regrets not speaking to patients and their families caught up in the Stafford Hospital scandal.

item.title: Labour promises 'balanced' recovery
item.description: Labour's Chuka Umunna warns against a policy of "permanent austerity" and promises a "balanced" economic recovery.

item.title: New magnetic material discovered
item.description: A highly sensitive magnetic material that could transform computer hard drives and energy storage devices has been discovered.

item.title: 'Surrender' call and economic threat - front pages
item.description: The crisis in Ukraine continues to dominate the front pages, as some papers report that Russia is threatening "all-out war" and others examine the economic fallout.

item.title: 30,000-year-old virus is revived
item.description: An ancient virus has been brought back to life after lying dormant for 30,000 years in the Siberian permafrost, scientists say.

item.title: Twitter resets passwords by accident
item.description: Thousands of users told to change passwords due to "compromised accounts" - but it has since said the emails were sent by mistake.

item.title: Smith a captaincy great, says Stewart
item.description: South African batsman Graeme Smith is one of the game's greatest captains, says former England skipper Alec Stewart.

item.title: Captain Brown recalled by Scotland
item.description: Saracens' Kelly Brown is back in Scotland's starting line-up to face France and will be captain at Murrayfield.

item.title: Wembley to host Froch-Groves rematch
item.description: Carl Froch and George Groves' rematch will take place at Wembley Stadium on 31 May, promoter Eddie Hearn announces.

item.title: Pressure starting to rise on Brazil
item.description: With 100 days to go before the World Cup begins in Brazil and the clock ticking, Tim Vickery looks at issues affecting the hosts.

item.title: 'Giles can make England world-beaters'
item.description: Graeme Swann backs Ashley Giles to be England's permanent head coach and believes the team can return to the top in all formats.

item.title: Markets steady despite Ukraine fears
item.description: Global markets steady on Tuesday, with Russian markets up 5%, as the country says it may abandon the US dollar as a reserve currency.

item.title: AUDIO: 'Ukraine crisis may hit gas prices'
item.description: UK gas prices could rise as a result of the Ukraine crisis, a leading energy consultant has warned.

item.title: Cameron 'shocked' by aide claims
item.description: David Cameron says he feels "profoundly shocked" by allegations against an aide arrested on suspicion of an offence "relating to child abuse imagery".

item.title: VIDEO: Parliamentarians caught flipping again
item.description: MPs, peers and the press pack compete in the annual Parliamentary pancake race held in Victoria Tower Gardens.

item.title: One in five 'admits misusing A&E '
item.description: Nearly one in five patients in England admits they have misused A&E at some point, a survey suggests.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Millions lost' to missed appointments
item.description: The NHS says it has lost millions of pounds in the last year because of the number of patients failing to turn up for appointments.

item.title: 'Too long' to sack poor teachers
item.description: Poorly performing teachers in Wales can take too long to sack, a BBC investigation finds.

item.title: AUDIO: Online courses 'create divisions'
item.description: Mary Beard and Martin Bean discuss the opportunities and potential problems created by massive open online courses (Moocs).

item.title: MtGox gives bankruptcy details
item.description: The troubled Bitcoin exchange, which filed for bankruptcy on Friday, releases a statement giving more details of the problems that caused it to close down.

item.title: AUDIO: Lasers speed up New York share trades
item.description: Mike Persico discusses his firm's plans to introduce laser beam connectivity between the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq.

item.title: 'Fewer crops' now feeding the world
item.description: Fewer crop species are feeding the world than 50 years ago, raising concerns about the resilience and nutritional value of the global food system, a study says.

item.title: VIDEO: Arctic summit starts in London
item.description: Oil, mining and shipping companies are debating the Arctic's business and geopolitical future at a two-day summit in London.

item.title: Oscars watched by 43m viewers in US
item.description: Sunday's Academy Awards ceremony was watched by 43 million TV viewers in the US, according to early figures.

item.title: VIDEO: Cherub author begins a Rock War
item.description: A decade after beginning his successful Cherub series, best-selling children's author, Robert Muchamore, publishes his new book, Rock War.

item.title: How does a snake eat a crocodile?
item.description: Onlookers at a lake in Queensland watched a water python kill and swallow a crocodile. How do they do this?

item.title: Helvetica: How did one typeface conquer the world?
item.description: Mike Parker who helped popularise the typeface Helvetica died this week. You won't find a graphic designer who isn't familiar with it. Why is that, asks David Airey.

item.title: Bone found in missing teenager case
item.description: Police investigating the disappearance of a Suffolk teenager in 2006 find human remains during a search of woodland.

item.title: IPCC probes Jayden police response
item.description: The police response to the disappearance of teenager Jayden Parkinson is being investigated by the police watchdog.

item.title: Scotland 'facing poverty crisis'
item.description: A campaign aimed at highlighting the "humanitarian crisis" caused by poverty in Scotland is launched by a group of major charities.

item.title: Alex Salmond 'ban' to be abandoned
item.description: Moves to ban Alex Salmond and his Scottish ministerial team from Aberdeen council buildings look set to be abandoned.

item.title: Paralympic athlete pleads guilty
item.description: Jordanian Paralympic athlete Omar Qaradhi pleads guilty to sexually assaulting a woman and two girls in Northern Ireland.

item.title: UFU welcomes 'illegal meat' searches
item.description: A police operation that uncovered a suspected illegal animal slaughter and meat operation in County Armagh is welcomed by the Ulster Farmers' Union.

item.title: 123 steelworks jobs under threat
item.description: A total of 123 jobs are set to be axed under plans to restructure a Newport steel plant due to reduced demand for products, say bosses.

item.title: Dogs destroyed after baby death
item.description: Two dogs are destroyed following the death of six-day-old Eliza-Mae Mullane, police confirm.

item.title: 'Protection squad' for UN in Somalia
item.description: Uganda will send a 410-strong special force to guard UN installations in Somalia's capital Mogadishu, a Ugandan army spokesman says.

item.title: Sisi hints at Egypt presidential bid
item.description: Egypt's armed forces chief, Field Marshal Abdul Fattah al-Sisi, says he cannot ignore calls by the majority for him to run for president.

item.title: US calls Kunming attack 'terrorism'
item.description: The US describes Saturday's deadly knife attack in China's Kunming as "an act of terrorism", amid Chinese criticism of double standards.

item.title: India tycoon's custody extended
item.description: Indian businessman Subrata Roy is attacked with ink outside the Supreme Court, which orders him remain in custody in a multi-billion dollar fraud case.

item.title: Sport results hit Paddy Power profit
item.description: Irish bookmaker Paddy Power sees a record pre-tax profit in 2013, despite an "exceptional run of punter-friendly sports results".

item.title: Croatia accuses Serbia of genocide
item.description: Croatia tells the top UN court Serbian leaders are "in denial" over a "genocide policy" carried out on Croatian territory in the 1990s.

item.title: UN chief urges dialogue in Venezuela
item.description: United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon urges Venezuela to hear the demands of anti-government protesters and talk to the opposition.

item.title: Nicaraguan leader re-emerges
item.description: Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega appears in public after an absence of 10 days which led to speculation he was sick or had died.

item.title: Egyptian court ruling bans Hamas
item.description: A court in Egypt bans all activities by the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas and orders the seizure of its offices and assets.

item.title: Obama: 'Tough choices' for Netanyahu
item.description: US President Barack Obama warns that Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu must make "tough decisions" to advance peace talks with the Palestinians.

item.title: UN hits at US cannabis legalisation
item.description: A UN illegal drugs body criticises 2012 moves in two US states to legalise recreational marijuana, saying they contravene drug control treaties.

item.title: US court rejects BP payment appeal
item.description: A US federal court rejects BP's efforts to halt payments to businesses relating to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, leaving the firm with potentially billions more in liabilities.

item.title: Day in pictures: 4 March 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 4 March

item.title: In pictures: Escalating Ukraine tensions
item.description: Russia tightens military grip on the Crimea

item.title: In pictures: Oscars ceremony 2014
item.description: The winners and on-stage antics

item.title: Week in pictures: 22-28 February 2014
item.description: News photos from around the world

item.title: In pictures: Excavating past crimes in Somaliland
item.description: Excavating past crimes in Somaliland's graves

item.title: Day in pictures: 28 February 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 28 February

item.title: Your pictures: Doors
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of doors

item.title: In pictures: London now and then
item.description: Hybrid images from the Museum of London

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs are taking part in a debate on public spending for defence and cyber security.

item.title: VIDEO: Spacemen pay tribute to Gravity film
item.description: Astronauts aboard the International Space Stations send congratulations to the producers of 'Gravity' for their Oscars success

item.title: VIDEO: Vikings were 'artists not just brutes'
item.description: A new exhibition is showing off the softer side of Vikings, rather than portraying them as bloodthirsty barbarians wearing horned helmets.

item.title: VIDEO: Children to learn about loan sharks
item.description: School children in England are to have lessons warning them against using loan sharks.

item.title: VIDEO: Rio Carnival pays tribute to football
item.description: The annual Rio Carnival is in full swing and one samba school is exploring the link between Brazil's two favourite pastimes: carnival and football.

item.title: VIDEO: Student 'sugar babies' dating for cash
item.description: A BBC investigation finds a growing number of students are dating older men for money in order to help pay their tuition fees.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Superman suit' lets man lift 100kg
item.description: Engineers in Italy have developed a wearable robot which they claim is the most sophisticated built in the world to date.

item.title: VIDEO: Flood victims come face-to-face
item.description: A victim of the floods in Hull seven years ago spends time in Somerset where residents have experienced some of the area's worst ever flooding.

item.title: VIDEO: Benefits Street's 'White Dee' on fame
item.description: Deirdre Kelly, ''White Dee'' of Channel 4's Benefits Street, has told Newsnight's Emily Maitlis that being thrown into the world of television exposure was ''a real shock''.

item.title: The march of the postcode battlers
item.description: Why do people fight to shift from one code to another?

item.title: Rise of the human exoskeletons
item.description: A suit that makes you superhuman

item.title: The sanitary pad revolutionary
item.description: The school dropout who sparked a sanitary pad revolution in India

item.title: Molly on her Eurovision 'challenge'
item.description: UK singer Molly on her song contest challenge

item.title: VIDEO: Is it OK to bet on a murder trial?
item.description: Bookmaker under fire for offering bets on Pistorius trial

item.title: Calcium, building block for the world
item.description: The soft grey metal that built our world

item.title: Doctor Who's longest-serving director and Top of the Pops disc spinner
item.description: Dr Who director and Top of the Pops disc spinner

item.title: Heath, Thorpe and the lost coalition of 1974
item.description: The story of Ted Heath and Jeremy Thorpe's doomed deal

item.title: Big Data: Are you ready for blast-off?
item.description: Are you ready for the Big Data revolution?

item.title: Who loses from punishing Russia?
item.description: Imposing sanctions on Russia would not be cheap or painless

item.title: Can Taliban ceasefire prevent bloodshed?
item.description: The many factors that can undermine a ceasefire in Pakistan
